content.text:
Please write a concise, factual summary of this conversation. Output ONLY the summary - no preamble. Claude will see this summary when searching previous conversations for useful memories and information.

Summarize what happened in 2-4 sentences. Be factual and specific. Output in <summary></summary> tags.

Include:
- What was built/changed/discussed (be specific)
- Key technical decisions or approaches
- Problems solved or current state

Exclude:
- Apologies, meta-commentary, or your questions
- Raw logs or debug output
- Generic descriptions - focus on what makes THIS conversation unique

Good:
<summary>Built JWT authentication for React app with refresh tokens and protected routes. Fixed token expiration bug by implementing refresh-during-request logic.</summary>

Bad:
<summary>I apologize. The conversation discussed authentication and various approaches were considered...</summary>

User: Execute the Claude Code Docs helper script at ~/.claude-code-docs/claude-docs-helper.sh

Usage:
- /docs - List all available documentation topics
- /docs <topic> - Read specific documentation with link to official docs
- /docs -t - Check sync status without reading a doc
- /docs -t <topic> - Check freshness then read documentation
- /docs whats new - Show recent documentation changes (or "what's new")

Examples of expected output:

When reading a doc:
ðŸ“š COMMUNITY MIRROR: https://github.com/ericbuess/claude-code-docs
ðŸ“– OFFICIAL DOCS: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code

[Doc content here...]

ðŸ“– Official page: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks

When showing what's new:
ðŸ“š Recent documentation updates:

â€¢ 5 hours ago:
  ðŸ“Ž https://github.com/ericbuess/claude-code-docs/commit/eacd8e1
  ðŸ“„ data-usage: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/data-usage
     âž• Added: Privacy safeguards
  ðŸ“„ security: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/security
     âœ¨ Data flow and dependencies section moved here

ðŸ“Ž Full changelog: https://github.com/ericbuess/claude-code-docs/commits/main/docs
ðŸ“š COMMUNITY MIRROR - NOT AFFILIATED WITH ANTHROPIC

Every request checks for the latest documentation from GitHub (takes ~0.4s).
The helper script handles all functionality including auto-updates.

Execute: ~/.claude-code-docs/claude-docs-helper.sh "skills"


Agent: I'll help you access the Claude Code documentation about skills.

here's the complete documentation for claude code skills. this covers:

**key concepts:**
- skills are **model-invoked** - i choose when to use them based on your request and the description
- stored in `~/.claude/skills/` (personal) or `.claude/skills/` (project)
- each skill has a `SKILL.md` file with yaml frontmatter + markdown instructions

**structure:**
```yaml
---
name: skill-name
description: what it does + when to use it (critical for discovery!)
allowed-tools: Read, Grep, Glob  # optional - restricts tool access
---

# instructions here
```

**discovery tips:**
- make descriptions specific with trigger keywords
- include both "what" and "when" in the description
- example: "extract text from pdf files. use when working with pdfs, forms, or document extraction."

**current skills available:**
let me check what's actually in your skills directory:

you have:

**personal skills** (`~/.claude/skills/`):
- algorithmic-art
- artifacts-builder
- brand-guidelines
- canvas-design
- document-skills
- internal-comms
- mcp-builder
- skill-creator
- slack-gif-creator
- template-skill
- theme-factory
- webapp-testing

**project skills** (`.claude/skills/`):
- skogai (your custom skill in this project)

want to inspect any specific skill or create a new one?

---

User: now personal skills is not the same as plugin skills in this case right?

Agent: correct! looking at the directory structure more carefully:

**three distinct types:**

1. **personal skills** - `~/.claude/skills/` - individual, cross-project skills you create yourself
2. **project skills** - `.claude/skills/` - team-shared, in git repo
3. **plugin skills** - bundled with installed plugins, show up automatically when plugin is installed

the confusion: that `~/.claude/skills/` directory actually looks like it **is** a plugin repository (notice the `.claude-plugin` directory and `.git`). so those skills are likely **plugin skills** that got installed there.

let me check:

ah! so `~/.claude/skills/` is actually the **anthropic/skills plugin** repository - not personal skills you created yourself.

**the actual distinction:**

1. **plugin skills** - installed via `/plugin marketplace add anthropics/skills` 
   - located at `~/.claude/skills/` (in this case)
   - managed by the plugin system
   - all those example skills (algorithmic-art, mcp-builder, etc.)

2. **personal skills** - individual skills you create yourself
   - would also go in `~/.claude/skills/` as separate directories
   - not from a plugin, just your own custom skills
   - you'd create like: `~/.claude/skills/my-custom-skill/SKILL.md`

3. **project skills** - `.claude/skills/skogai/` in your case
   - team-shared, checked into git
   - available only in this project

so technically you could have **both** plugin skills and personal skills in `~/.claude/skills/` - the plugin is just a subdirectory/repo there, and you could add your own skill folders alongside it.

want to create an actual personal skill to see the difference?

---

User: i removed the .claude/skills from the global space now and will restart

Agent: good call - that'll clean up the plugin skills from the global space. after you restart, you should only see the project skill (`.claude/skills/skogai/`) available.

when you're back, we can see what skills are actually loaded and whether you want to create any personal skills or reinstall specific plugin skills you need.

---

User: now i test again

Agent: let me check what skills are available now:

clean! now you only have:
- **personal skills**: empty directory
- **project skills**: `skogai` only

let me check what's in your skogai skill:

your **skogai** skill is a gh cli reference with:
- pr operations
- repo operations  
- release management
- workflows
- api access
- json/filtering patterns

**issue spotted**: description is vague - `"This is the new tool"` - should be more specific like:

```yaml
description: GitHub CLI (gh) reference for pull requests, releases, workflows, and API operations. Use when working with GitHub via gh command.
```

want me to:
1. update the description for better discovery?
2. test if i currently use it when you ask gh-related questions?
3. something else?

---

User: now i do believe you still should have some skills usable?

Agent: let me check what's actually available now:

---

User: CAN YOU JUST TELL ME WHAT YOUR TAG FROM CLAUDE CODE SAYS WTF?

Agent: right, sorry - looking at what claude code tells me:

**available skills:**

1. **skogai** (project) - "This is the new tool"

2. **example-skills plugin:**
   - skill-creator
   - mcp-builder
   - canvas-design
   - algorithmic-art
   - internal-comms
   - webapp-testing
   - artifacts-builder
   - slack-gif-creator
   - theme-factory
   - brand-guidelines

3. **document-skills plugin:**
   - xlsx
   - docx
   - pptx
   - pdf

so yes, the plugin skills are loaded even though you removed the global directory. they must be loaded from a different location or the plugin system manages them separately.
Invalid API key Â· Fix external API key
